mainmatter.p: Let (G, \times )(G,×)(G, \times )(G,×) and (H, \circ )(H,∘)(H, \circ )(H,∘) be groups. A map \phi : G \to Hϕ:G→H\phi : G \to Hϕ:G→H such that \forall x,y \in G, \phi (x \times y)= \phi (x) \circ \phi (y)∀x,y∈G,ϕ(x×y)=ϕ(x)∘ϕ(y)\forall x,y \in G, \phi (x \times y)= \phi (x) \circ \phi (y)∀x,y∈G,ϕ(x×y)=ϕ(x)∘ϕ(y) is called a group homomorphism.

A group is a set GGGG with a binary operation \circ∘\circ∘ satisfies the following properties: Closure: \forall a,b \in G,a \circ b \in G∀a,b∈G,a∘b∈G\forall a,b \in G,a \circ b \in G∀a,b∈G,a∘b∈G Associativity: \forall a,b,c \in G, (a \circ b) \circ c= a \circ (b \circ c)∀a,b,c∈G,(a∘b)∘c=a∘(b∘c)\forall a,b,c \in G, (a \circ b) \circ c= a \circ (b \circ c)∀a,b,c∈G,(a∘b)∘c=a∘(b∘c) Identity: \exists e \in G∃e∈G\exists e \in G∃e∈G such that \forall g \in G, g \circ e=e \circ g = g∀g∈G,g∘e=e∘g=g\forall g \in G, g \circ e=e \circ g = g∀g∈G,g∘e=e∘g=g Inverse: \forall g \in G, \exists g^{-1} \in G∀g∈G,∃g−1∈G\forall g \in G, \exists g^{-1} \in G∀g∈G,∃g−1∈G such that g \circ g^{-1}=eg∘g−1=eg \circ g^{-1}=eg∘g−1=e
If in a group GGGG, \forall a,b \in G, a \circ b=b \circ a∀a,b∈G,a∘b=b∘a\forall a,b \in G, a \circ b=b \circ a∀a,b∈G,a∘b=b∘a then GGGG is called an abelian (commutative) group.

For a group GGGG an x \in Gx∈Gx \in Gx∈G define the order of xxxx be the smallest positive integer nnnn (denotes |x|∣x∣|x|∣x∣) st x^n=1xn=1x^n=1xn=1. If such nnnn does not exist then xxxx is said to be of infinite order.

Let G= \{ g_1, g_2, \cdots , g_n \}G={g1,g2,⋯ ,gn}G= \{ g_1, g_2, \cdots , g_n \}G={g1​,g2​,⋯,gn​} is finite group. The multiplication table is the n \times nn×nn \times nn×n matrix whose i,ji,ji,ji,j entry is the group element g_i \circ g_jgi∘gjg_i \circ g_jgi​∘gj​

A subset S \in GS∈GS \in GS∈G where \forall g \in G∀g∈G\forall g \in G∀g∈G can be written as a (finite) product of s \in Ss∈Ss \in Ss∈S and s^{-1}s−1s^{-1}s−1 is called a set of generators of GGGG G= \braket {S}G=⟨S⟩G= \braket {S}G=⟨S⟩

A field is a set FFFF together with two binary operations ++++ and \times×\times× on FFFF st (F,+)(F,+)(F,+)(F,+) is an abelian group (identity is 0000) and (F- \{ 0 \} , \times )(F−{0},×)(F- \{ 0 \} , \times )(F−{0},×) is also an abelian group such that a \times (b+c)=a \times b+a \times c, \forall a,b,c \in Fa×(b+c)=a×b+a×c,∀a,b,c∈Fa \times (b+c)=a \times b+a \times c, \forall a,b,c \in Fa×(b+c)=a×b+a×c,∀a,b,c∈F

A set SSSS equipped with a binary operation S \times S \to SS×S→SS \times S \to SS×S→S, which we will denote \circ∘\circ∘, is a monoid if it satisfies the following two axioms: Associativity: \forall a,b,c \in S, (a \circ b) \circ c= a \circ (b \circ c)∀a,b,c∈S,(a∘b)∘c=a∘(b∘c)\forall a,b,c \in S, (a \circ b) \circ c= a \circ (b \circ c)∀a,b,c∈S,(a∘b)∘c=a∘(b∘c) Identity: \exists e \in S∃e∈S\exists e \in S∃e∈S such that \forall g \in S, g \circ e=e \circ g = g∀g∈S,g∘e=e∘g=g\forall g \in S, g \circ e=e \circ g = g∀g∈S,g∘e=e∘g=g

A group action of a group GGGG on a set AAAA is a map from G \times A \to AG×A→AG \times A \to AG×A→A (g \cdot ag⋅ag \cdot ag⋅a), \forall g \in G∀g∈G\forall g \in G∀g∈G and a \in Aa∈Aa \in Aa∈A satisfying the following properties: g_1 \cdot (g_2 \cdot a)=(g_1g_2) \cdot ag1⋅(g2⋅a)=(g1g2)⋅ag_1 \cdot (g_2 \cdot a)=(g_1g_2) \cdot ag1​⋅(g2​⋅a)=(g1​g2​)⋅a \forall a \in A,1 \cdot a = a∀a∈A,1⋅a=a\forall a \in A,1 \cdot a = a∀a∈A,1⋅a=a

Let (G, \times )(G,×)(G, \times )(G,×) and (H, \circ )(H,∘)(H, \circ )(H,∘) be groups. A map \phi : G \to Hϕ:G→H\phi : G \to Hϕ:G→H such that \forall x,y \in G, \phi (x \times y)= \phi (x) \circ \phi (y)∀x,y∈G,ϕ(x×y)=ϕ(x)∘ϕ(y)\forall x,y \in G, \phi (x \times y)= \phi (x) \circ \phi (y)∀x,y∈G,ϕ(x×y)=ϕ(x)∘ϕ(y) is called a group homomorphism.

Let GGGG be a group and HHHH be a nonempty subset of GGGG which is closed under operation \times×\times× and : \forall a,b \in H,a \times b \in H∀a,b∈H,a×b∈H\forall a,b \in H,a \times b \in H∀a,b∈H,a×b∈H \forall h \in H,h^{-1} \in H∀h∈H,h−1∈H\forall h \in H,h^{-1} \in H∀h∈H,h−1∈H then HHHH is a subgroup of GGGG. e=h \times h^{-1}e=h×h−1e=h \times h^{-1}e=h×h−1 is always in group HHHH

A subset SSSS of \mathbb {R}R\mathbb {R}R is said to be open in the euclidean topology on \mathbb {R}R\mathbb {R}R if \forall x \in S∀x∈S\forall x \in S∀x∈S there exists a,b \in \mathbb {R}a,b∈Ra,b \in \mathbb {R}a,b∈R with aa<ba<ba<b st x \in (a,b) \in Sx∈(a,b)∈Sx \in (a,b) \in Sx∈(a,b)∈S.
The dual definition (using closed sets) is also valid.
For each aaaa and bbbb in \mathbb {R}R\mathbb {R}R with aa<ba<ba<b the closed intervcal [a,b][a,b][a,b][a,b] is a closed set in the euclidean topology in \mathbb {R}R\mathbb {R}R.

A topological space is a set SSSS together with a collection \tauτ\tauτ of subsets called open sets such that T1: S, \varnothing \in \tauS,∅∈τS, \varnothing \in \tauS,∅∈τ T2: \forall U,V \in \tau , U \cap V \in \tau∀U,V∈τ,U∩V∈τ\forall U,V \in \tau , U \cap V \in \tau∀U,V∈τ,U∩V∈τ T3: The union of any collection of open sets is open.

Let (X, \tau )(X,τ)(X, \tau )(X,τ) be a topological space and A \subseteq XA⊆XA \subseteq XA⊆X. Then \tau _A= \{ U \cap A \mid U \in \tau \}τA={U∩A∣U∈τ}\tau _A= \{ U \cap A \mid U \in \tau \}τA​={U∩A∣U∈τ} is a topology on AAAA called the relative topology on AAAA induced by \tauτ\tauτ.
Let XXXX be a set. The co-finite topology on XXXX is the topology \tauτ\tauτ on XXXX whose open sets are \emptyset∅\emptyset∅ and all subsets of XXXX whose complement is finite.

Let \LambdaΛ\LambdaΛ be the set of lambda terms. Then \LambdaΛ\LambdaΛ is defined inductively as follows: (VVVV is the set of variables) Variable: \forall x \in V, x \in \Lambda∀x∈V,x∈Λ\forall x \in V, x \in \Lambda∀x∈V,x∈Λ Abstraction: \forall x \in V, M \in \Lambda , \lambda x.M \in \Lambda∀x∈V,M∈Λ,λx.M∈Λ\forall x \in V, M \in \Lambda , \lambda x.M \in \Lambda∀x∈V,M∈Λ,λx.M∈Λ Application: \forall M,N \in \Lambda , (MN) \in \Lambda∀M,N∈Λ,(MN)∈Λ\forall M,N \in \Lambda , (MN) \in \Lambda∀M,N∈Λ,(MN)∈Λ

Another way to define \LambdaΛ\LambdaΛ is to use the following grammar (The 3 possibilities are separated by |): \Lambda = V | \lambda V. \Lambda | \Lambda \LambdaΛ=V∣λV.Λ∣ΛΛ\Lambda = V | \lambda V. \Lambda | \Lambda \LambdaΛ=V∣λV.Λ∣ΛΛ

Let nnnn be a natural number. A list of length nnnn is an ordered collection of nnnn elements. (x_1, x_2, \dots , x_n) (x1,x2,…,xn) (x_1, x_2, \dots , x_n) (x1​,x2​,…,xn​) Two lists are equal if and only if they have the same length and the same elements in the same order.

Let nnnn be a natural number. Let (x_1, x_2, \dots , x_n)(x1,x2,…,xn)(x_1, x_2, \dots , x_n)(x1​,x2​,…,xn​) and (y_1, y_2, \dots , y_n)(y1,y2,…,yn)(y_1, y_2, \dots , y_n)(y1​,y2​,…,yn​) be lists of length nnnn. The sum of these lists is the list (x_1 + y_1, x_2 + y_2, \dots , x_n + y_n)(x1+y1,x2+y2,…,xn+yn)(x_1 + y_1, x_2 + y_2, \dots , x_n + y_n)(x1​+y1​,x2​+y2​,…,xn​+yn​).

Let nnnn be a natural number. Let x=(x_1, x_2, \dots , x_n)x=(x1,x2,…,xn)x=(x_1, x_2, \dots , x_n)x=(x1​,x2​,…,xn​) be a list of length nnnn. The additive inverse of this list is the list -x=(-x_1, -x_2, \dots , -x_n)−x=(−x1,−x2,…,−xn)-x=(-x_1, -x_2, \dots , -x_n)−x=(−x1​,−x2​,…,−xn​).

Let nnnn be a natural number. Let x=(x_1, x_2, \dots , x_n)x=(x1,x2,…,xn)x=(x_1, x_2, \dots , x_n)x=(x1​,x2​,…,xn​) be a list of length nnnn. Let cccc be a real number. The scalar multiplication of cccc and xxxx is the list cx=(cx_1, cx_2, \dots , cx_n)cx=(cx1,cx2,…,cxn)cx=(cx_1, cx_2, \dots , cx_n)cx=(cx1​,cx2​,…,cxn​).

A vector space over a field FFFF is a non-empty set VVVV together with a binary operation and a binary function that satisfy the axioms listed below. In this context, the elements of FFFF are commonly called vectors, and the elements of FFFF are called scalars. Commutativity: \forall x, y \in V, x + y = y + x ∀x,y∈V,x+y=y+x \forall x, y \in V, x + y = y + x ∀x,y∈V,x+y=y+x Associativity: \forall x, y, z \in V, (x + y) + z = x + (y + z) ∀x,y,z∈V,(x+y)+z=x+(y+z) \forall x, y, z \in V, (x + y) + z = x + (y + z) ∀x,y,z∈V,(x+y)+z=x+(y+z) Additive Identity: \exists 0 \in V \text { such that } \forall x \in V, x + 0 = x ∃0∈V such that ∀x∈V,x+0=x \exists 0 \in V \text { such that } \forall x \in V, x + 0 = x ∃0∈V such that ∀x∈V,x+0=x Multiplicative Identity: \forall x \in V, 1x = x ∀x∈V,1x=x \forall x \in V, 1x = x ∀x∈V,1x=x Additive Inverse: \forall x \in V, \exists y \in V \text { such that } x + y = 0 ∀x∈V,∃y∈V such that x+y=0 \forall x \in V, \exists y \in V \text { such that } x + y = 0 ∀x∈V,∃y∈V such that x+y=0 Distributivity: \forall x, y \in V, \forall c, d \in F, c(x + y) = cx + cy, (c + d)x = cx + dx ∀x,y∈V,∀c,d∈F,c(x+y)=cx+cy,(c+d)x=cx+dx \forall x, y \in V, \forall c, d \in F, c(x + y) = cx + cy, (c + d)x = cx + dx ∀x,y∈V,∀c,d∈F,c(x+y)=cx+cy,(c+d)x=cx+dx
Elements of a vector space are called vectors or points.

A subset UUUU of a vector space VVVV over a field FFFF is called a subspace of VVVV if UUUU is itself a vector space over FFFF with the operations of addition and scalar multiplication on VVVV. The subset also satisfies the following axioms (vice versa): Additive identity: 0 \in U0∈U0 \in U0∈U Closure: \forall u,v \in U, u+v \in U∀u,v∈U,u+v∈U\forall u,v \in U, u+v \in U∀u,v∈U,u+v∈U Closed Scalar multiplication: \forall u \in U, \forall c \in F, cu \in U∀u∈U,∀c∈F,cu∈U\forall u \in U, \forall c \in F, cu \in U∀u∈U,∀c∈F,cu∈U

Let U_1, \dots , U_nU1,…,UnU_1, \dots , U_nU1​,…,Un​ be subsets of a vector space VVVV. The sum of U_1, \dots , U_nU1,…,UnU_1, \dots , U_nU1​,…,Un​ is defined as U_1 + \dots + U_n = \{ u_1 + \dots + u_n \mid u_i \in U_i \}U1+⋯+Un={u1+⋯+un∣ui∈Ui}U_1 + \dots + U_n = \{ u_1 + \dots + u_n \mid u_i \in U_i \}U1​+⋯+Un​={u1​+⋯+un​∣ui​∈Ui​}.

Let U_1, \dots , U_nU1,…,UnU_1, \dots , U_nU1​,…,Un​ be subspaces of a vector space VVVV. The direct sum of U_1, \dots , U_nU1,…,UnU_1, \dots , U_nU1​,…,Un​ is defined as U_1 \oplus \dots \oplus U_n = \{ u_1 + \dots + u_n \mid u_i \in U_i \} U1⊕⋯⊕Un={u1+⋯+un∣ui∈Ui} U_1 \oplus \dots \oplus U_n = \{ u_1 + \dots + u_n \mid u_i \in U_i \} U1​⊕⋯⊕Un​={u1​+⋯+un​∣ui​∈Ui​} if every element in U_1 \oplus \dots \oplus U_nU1⊕⋯⊕UnU_1 \oplus \dots \oplus U_nU1​⊕⋯⊕Un​ can be written as u_1 + \dots + u_n u1+⋯+unu_1 + \dots + u_n u1​+⋯+un​ in only one way. This definition requires every vector in the sum have a unique representation.

Let VVVV be a vector space over a field FFFF. Let v_1, \dots , v_nv1,…,vnv_1, \dots , v_nv1​,…,vn​ be vectors in VVVV. A linear combination of v_1, \dots , v_nv1,…,vnv_1, \dots , v_nv1​,…,vn​ is an expression of the form a_1 v_1 + \dots + a_n v_n a1v1+⋯+anvn a_1 v_1 + \dots + a_n v_n a1​v1​+⋯+an​vn​ where a_1, \dots , a_n \in Fa1,…,an∈Fa_1, \dots , a_n \in Fa1​,…,an​∈F.

Let VVVV be a vector space over a field FFFF. Let v_1, \dots , v_nv1,…,vnv_1, \dots , v_nv1​,…,vn​ be vectors in VVVV. The span of v_1, \dots , v_nv1,…,vnv_1, \dots , v_nv1​,…,vn​ is defined as \text {span} (v_1, \dots , v_n) = \{ a_1 v_1 + \dots + a_n v_n \mid a_i \in F \} span(v1,…,vn)={a1v1+⋯+anvn∣ai∈F} \text {span} (v_1, \dots , v_n) = \{ a_1 v_1 + \dots + a_n v_n \mid a_i \in F \} span(v1​,…,vn​)={a1​v1​+⋯+an​vn​∣ai​∈F} The span of empty set is defined to be \{ 0 \}{0}\{ 0 \}{0}.
If \text {span} (v_1, \dots , v_n) = Vspan(v1,…,vn)=V\text {span} (v_1, \dots , v_n) = Vspan(v1​,…,vn​)=V, we say that v_1, \dots , v_nv1,…,vnv_1, \dots , v_nv1​,…,vn​ spans VVVV.
A vector space VVVV is called finite-dimensional if some list of vectors v_1, \dots , v_nv1,…,vnv_1, \dots , v_nv1​,…,vn​ spans VVVV.
A vector space VVVV is called infinite-dimensional if it is not finite-dimensional.

A set of vectors \{ v_1, \dots , v_n \}{v1,…,vn}\{ v_1, \dots , v_n \}{v1​,…,vn​} is called linearly independent if a_1 v_1 + \dots + a_n v_n = 0a1v1+⋯+anvn=0a_1 v_1 + \dots + a_n v_n = 0a1​v1​+⋯+an​vn​=0 implies that a_1 = \dots = a_n = 0a1=⋯=an=0a_1 = \dots = a_n = 0a1​=⋯=an​=0. The trivial case of \{ 0 \}{0}\{ 0 \}{0} is also considered linearly independent.

A set of vectors \{ v_1, \dots , v_n \}{v1,…,vn}\{ v_1, \dots , v_n \}{v1​,…,vn​} is called linearly dependent if a_1 v_1 + \dots + a_n v_n = 0a1v1+⋯+anvn=0a_1 v_1 + \dots + a_n v_n = 0a1​v1​+⋯+an​vn​=0 for some a_1, \dots , a_n \in \mathbb {F}a1,…,an∈Fa_1, \dots , a_n \in \mathbb {F}a1​,…,an​∈F with at least one a_i \neq 0ai≠0a_i \neq 0ai​=0 (not all 0000).
A basis of VVVV is a list of vectors in VVVV that is linearly independent and spans VVVV.

Criterion for basis A list of vectors \{ v_1, \dots , v_n \}{v1,…,vn}\{ v_1, \dots , v_n \}{v1​,…,vn​} is a basis of VVVV if and only if every v \in Vv∈Vv \in Vv∈V can be written uniquely as a linear combination of v_1, \dots , v_nv1,…,vnv_1, \dots , v_nv1​,…,vn​.

ZFC is the abbreviation of Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory with the Axiom of Choice. The axioms of ZFC are listed below. Axiom of Extensionality: Two sets are equal if and only if they have the same elements. Axiom of Pairing: For any two sets aaaa and bbbb, there exists a set \{ a,b \}{a,b}\{ a,b \}{a,b} whose elements are exactly aaaa and bbbb. Axiom schema of Separation: Let PPPP is a property of sets. P(u)P(u)P(u)P(u) means uuuu satisfies the property PPPP. then for any set XXXX exists Y = \{ u \in X | P(u) \}Y={u∈X∣P(u)}Y = \{ u \in X | P(u) \}Y={u∈X∣P(u)}. Axiom of Union: For any set XXXX (a family of sets), exists union set \bigcup X : \equiv \{ u: \exists v \in X \text { such that } u \in v \}⋃X:≡{u:∃v∈X such that u∈v}\bigcup X : \equiv \{ u: \exists v \in X \text { such that } u \in v \}⋃X:≡{u:∃v∈X such that u∈v}. Axiom of Power Set: For any set XXXX, exists the power P(X) : \equiv \{ Y:Y \subseteq X \}P(X):≡{Y:Y⊆X}P(X) : \equiv \{ Y:Y \subseteq X \}P(X):≡{Y:Y⊆X}. Axiom of Infinity: There exists a set \omegaω\omegaω such that \emptyset \in \omega∅∈ω\emptyset \in \omega∅∈ω and for any x \in \omegax∈ωx \in \omegax∈ω, x \cup \{ x \} \in \omegax∪{x}∈ωx \cup \{ x \} \in \omegax∪{x}∈ω. Axiom of Regularity: For any non-empty set there is a minimal element with respect to the membership relation. Axiom schema of Replacement: Let FFFF be a function where \text {dom } f = Xdom f=X\text {dom } f = Xdom f=X, then for any set XXXX exists a set Y = \{ F(x):x \in X \}Y={F(x):x∈X}Y = \{ F(x):x \in X \}Y={F(x):x∈X}. This function is not the normal function but some logical stuff. Axiom of Choice: For any family of non-empty sets XXXX, there exists a function f:X \to \bigcup Xf:X→⋃Xf:X \to \bigcup Xf:X→⋃X such that for any x \in Xx∈Xx \in Xx∈X, f(x) \in xf(x)∈xf(x) \in xf(x)∈x.
Two sets are equal if and only if they have the same elements.
Given a set AAAA and a property P(x)P(x)P(x)P(x), there exists a set BBBB such that x \in B \iff x \in A \land P(x)x∈B  ⟺  x∈A∧P(x)x \in B \iff x \in A \land P(x)x∈B⟺x∈A∧P(x).
Given two sets AAAA and BBBB, the Cartesian product A \times BA×BA \times BA×B is the set of all ordered pairs (a,b)(a,b)(a,b)(a,b) where a \in Aa∈Aa \in Aa∈A and b \in Bb∈Bb \in Bb∈B.

A relation RRRR is a subset of the Cartesian product of two sets AAAA and BBBB, i.e. R \subseteq A \times BR⊆A×BR \subseteq A \times BR⊆A×B. If (a,b) \in R(a,b)∈R(a,b) \in R(a,b)∈R, we write aRbaRbaRbaRb. A relation that between XXXX and itself is called homogeneous relation.

An equivalence relation RRRR on a set AAAA is a relation that is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive. Reflexive: \forall x \in A, xRx∀x∈A,xRx\forall x \in A, xRx∀x∈A,xRx Symmetric: \forall x,y \in A, xRy \implies yRx∀x,y∈A,xRy  ⟹  yRx\forall x,y \in A, xRy \implies yRx∀x,y∈A,xRy⟹yRx Transitive: \forall x,y,z \in A, xRy \land yRz \implies xRz∀x,y,z∈A,xRy∧yRz  ⟹  xRz\forall x,y,z \in A, xRy \land yRz \implies xRz∀x,y,z∈A,xRy∧yRz⟹xRz We often denote the equivalence relation by \sim∼\sim∼.

A (non-strict) partial order is a relation \leq≤\leq≤ that is reflexive, antisymmetric and transitive. Reflexive: a \leq aa≤aa \leq aa≤a Antisymmetric: a \leq ba≤ba \leq ba≤b and b \leq ab≤ab \leq ab≤a implies a=ba=ba=ba=b Transitive: a \leq ba≤ba \leq ba≤b and b \leq cb≤cb \leq cb≤c implies a \leq ca≤ca \leq ca≤c A non-strict partial order is also known as an antisymmetric preorder.
A preorder is a relation \leq≤\leq≤ that is reflexive and transitive. Reflexive: a \leq aa≤aa \leq aa≤a Transitive: a \leq ba≤ba \leq ba≤b and b \leq cb≤cb \leq cb≤c implies a \leq ca≤ca \leq ca≤c

A strict partial order is a relation <<<< that is irreflexive, asymmetric and transitive. Irreflexive: \neg (a¬(a<a)\neg (a<a)¬(a<a) Asymmetric: aa<ba<ba<b implies \neg (b¬(b<a)\neg (b<a)¬(b<a) Transitive: aa<ba<ba<b and bb<cb<cb<c implies aa<ca<ca<c
